sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x0=3. Use a tolerance of 0.0001 and perform 5 iterations.
message_2:
To apply the Newton-Raphson method, we need the derivative of the function f(x). The function is f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 - 5, so its derivative is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 4x

Now, we will perform 5 iterations of the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x0 = 3 and a tolerance of 0.0001.

Iteration 1:
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)
x1 = 3 - (3^3 - 2(3)^2 - 5) / (3(3)^2 - 4(3))
x1 = 3 - (27 - 18 - 5) / (27 - 12)
x1 = 3 - (4) / (15)
x1 ≈ 2.7333

Iteration 2:
x2 = x1 - f(x1) / f'(x1)
x2 = 2.7333 - ((2.7333)^3 - 2(2.7333)^2 - 5) / (3(2.7333)^2 - 4(2.7333))
x2 ≈ 2.6906

Iteration 3:
x3 = x2 - f(x2) / f'(x2)
x3 = 2.6906 - ((2.6906)^3 - 2(2.6906)^2 - 5) / (3(2.6906)^2 - 4(2.6906))
x3 ≈ 2.6904

Iteration 4:
x4 = x3 - f(x3) / f'(x3)
x4 = 2.6904 - ((2.6904)^3 - 2(2.6904)^2 - 5) / (3(2.6904)^2 - 4(2.6904))
x4 ≈ 2.6904

Iteration 5:
x5 = x4 - f(x4) / f'(x4)
x5 = 2.6904 - ((2.6904)^3 - 2(2.6904)^2 - 5) / (3(2.6904)^2 - 4(2.6904))
x5 ≈ 2.6904

After 5 iterations, the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 - 5 is approximately x ≈ 2.6904 with a tolerance of 0.0001.
